Turing Award 1977

Winner: John Backus

To help the programming difficulties of old calculators, in 1954 started a research project for IBM for the realisation of a programming language closer to a mathematical notation. The result of the project will then become “FORTRAN”, the first programming language of high level that had a great impact, also commercial, on the whole community of informatics.
After the realisation of FORTRAN , Backus has become an important member of the project specialized in the programming language ALGOL. In that context Backus proposed a new notation called BNF for the representation of the grammars used in the definition of a programming language.
In the 70’s Backus focused on functional programming, planning the programming language FP. His entire work on this, made functional programming a lot more accessible and started and important renaissance in research of the argument.

CITATION

In 1977 John Backus received the A.M. Turing award “For profound, influential, and lasting contributions to the design of practical high-level programming systems, notably through his work on FORTRAN, and for seminal publication of formal procedures for the specification of programming languages.” ~By anonymous speaker.
